title: Pt_09_b) 2020 Communication report - Lessons learnt_Appendix 1_Report on CoR communication activities in 2020
topics: Conference on the Future of Europe
classifications: economy, business and finance>economic sector>computing and information technology

policy.title: White paper on the future of Europe

people.snippet:
Before the general lockdown, the CoR organised a first consultation of citizens (5 March), with a view
to use it as an early contribution to the Conference on the Future of Europe. The Citizens’ Dialogue
in Cluj-Napoca was the first of this type. The debate focused on innovation and research, education and
youth, with the future “Horizon Europe” programme as an anchor for discussions. The dialogue also
took place back-to-back with the ‘StartUp Youth Innovation Camp’, thus providing the perfect opportunity
for a reality check on the ground. Around 130 participants debated lively on the spot with the Mayor of
Cluj, Emil Boc, and Commissioner Mariya Gabriel. The participation of the Commissioner demonstrated
the interest of the Commission to have a direct dialogue with citizens and cooperate with local and
regional authorities on the ground, opening up concrete avenues for fruitful collaboration with the CoR
as well. The event had a media coverage of 10 articles in the Romanian press. On 11 September, an
online debate with 360 young people from 15 countries on “the role of young people in the future of
Europe” accompanied the meeting of the CoR Bureau and was jointly organised with the State
Chancellery of the region of North Rhine-Westphalia on the occasion of the German Presidency.
Students and young people discussed with CoR President Apostolos Tzitzikostas, Stephan Holthoff-
Pförtner, European Affairs Minister of North Rhine-Westphalia, MEP Gabriele Bischoff, while Prof Dr
Michael Kaeding from the University of Duisburg-Essen was the moderator. Interpretation from/into
French, German, English, Italian, Spanish and Polish was offered through the “Interactio”
platform. Three topics were addressed: (1) Is Europe fit for the future? (2) What is the role of young
people in the ‘Conference on the Future of Europe’? (3) What specific action should local politicians take
to get young people interested in politics in general and Europe in particular? The event confirmed the
potential for such online debates with young people, cooperation with local organisers is key, a more
systematic and permanent dialogue with young people could be envisaged, and synergies with the
“Young Elected Politicians (YEP)” format of the CoR and initiative of other EU institutions such as the
EP’s “European Youth Event” (EYE) should be sought for, in particular with a view to the Conference
on the Future of Europe.

highlights.text: the ClosingSession 70 gave 5 stars. Other feedback from participants included requests for greatermultilingualism amongst speakers, and the inclusion of experts and organisations, which are workingon cutting edge technologies such as AI, online chat robots and speech recognition.
